awd_titl_txt: Geometric Scattering Theory, and Propagation and Decay of Waves
awd_abstract_narration:
The principal investigator will study mathematical problems in the subject of particle-wave duality. This duality has been successfully investigated for a long time, especially in the setting of closed systems, but many of its important manifestations are poorly understood, especially in the settings of open and mixed systems which are the principal investigator's focus. In open systems the method of complex scaling studied by the principal investigator appears in numerical analysis as the method of perfectly matched layers, where it has been useful in the engineering of nanostructures and microelectromechanical systems. Mixed systems like the ones studied by the principal investigator are important in electromagnetics, communications, optics, quantum waveguides, and semiconductors.

The main dynamical object studied by the principal investigator is the trapped set; this is the set of particle trajectories which remain in a bounded set for all time. The geometry of this set is of central importance in determining salient features of wave evolution, such as regularity, decay, and asymptotics. The principal investigator will study these features in the important but still comparatively mysterious situations of heavy trapping, rough coefficients, and noncompact trapped sets.

por.por_cntn:
There is a close relationship between behavior of waves and dynamics of an underlying system of particles. The foundational example, which has remained central to the cutting edge of research, is light, where the waves are electromagnetic waves and the particles are photons. Other important examples include acoustic and quantum waves.  The close relationship makes it possible to analyze salient properties of waves, and this project focused particularly on propagation and decay.

The setting of waveguides was studied in collaboration with T. J. Christiansen. These represent waves in a long, narrow passage, such as a cable or channel. Sharp wave decay rates, including precise asymptotics, were obtained for many different kinds of waveguides and more generally manifolds with cylindrical ends. The resolvent analysis techniques developed in the course of this project have had bearing on other scattering problems, particularly scattering by an obstacle in the plane such as an island in a body of water.

Scattering in low regularity was studied in collaboration with J. Shapiro.  This is of interest for waves propagating through media involving abrupt and irregular changes in the wavespeed. There wave decay can be slower, and we obtained precise bounds on what this decay can be via precise bounds on the corresponding semiclassical resolvent.

Scattering by thin barriers was studied in collaboration with N. Malawo, and with J. L. Marzuola and J. Wunsch. Such barriers are important in the study of quantum corrals, quantum dots, and leaky quantum graphs. There the effects of multiple diffractions were analyzed precisely in terms of resonances of the system. Diffractions are also important in many other physical situations, such as scattering from corners, and the examples studied here suggest results in those directions as well.

The broader impacts included work with undergraduates, resulting in the above mentioned paper joint with N. Malawo. Another undergraduate, E. Brady, completed an individual paper developing further the work with J. L. Marzuola and J. Wunsch. Further broader impacts took the form of mini-courses, including public and in one case published lecture notes and slides, in semiclassical analysis, scattering theory, and propagation of singularities taught at various conferences and graduate summer schools.
